title: My Lab Journal
text: This lab journal is used to document and present the results of the exercises for “Causal Data Science for Business Analytics”.

title: My Lab Journal
text:
How to use

Accept the assignment and get your own github repo.
Blog/journal what you are doing in R, by editing the .qmd files.
See the links page for lots of helpful links on learning R.
Change everything to make it your own.
Make sure to render you website every time before you want to upload changes.

title: Statistical Concepts
text:
This section will talk about statistical concepts, which are the basics in statistical and casual inference.
For the following assignments the table “random_vars.rds” is used.

title: Causality
text:
This section will deal with the topic of causality. This means the way one event influences another event. Furthermore it will deal with correlation and the risk of confusing correlation with causation.
To demonstrate this, a spurious correlation is plotted.









This spurious correlation “shows” that the number of worldwide non-comercial space launches correlates to the number of sociology doctorates awarded in the US.
One can easily figure out that there shouldn’t be any correlation between these two.
The data is from the following website: https://tylervigen.com/spurious-correlations

title: Directed Acyclic Graphs
text: This section will introduce an option to graphically represent the relationship between different variables with the help of directed acylic graphs (DAGs)

title: Randomized Controlled Trials
text:
This section will use the data from abtest_online.rds


#>       ip             chatbot        previous_visit   mobile_device  
#>  Length:1000        Mode :logical   Min.   : 0.000   Mode :logical  
#>  Class :character   FALSE:496       1st Qu.: 1.000   FALSE:683      
#>  Mode  :character   TRUE :504       Median : 1.000   TRUE :317      
#>                                     Mean   : 2.021                  
#>                                     3rd Qu.: 3.000                  
#>                                     Max.   :13.000                  
#>     purchase     purchase_amount
#>  Min.   :0.000   Min.   : 0.00  
#>  1st Qu.:0.000   1st Qu.: 0.00  
#>  Median :0.000   Median : 0.00  
#>  Mean   :0.381   Mean   :13.14  
#>  3rd Qu.:1.000   3rd Qu.:27.44  
#>  Max.   :1.000   Max.   :81.35



1 Check the balance of the covariates
















The plot shows the distribution of the two groups chatbot and no chatbot. As one can see the covariate of previous_visits is not balanced, while the covariate for mobile_device is balanced.


2 Regression to find the effect of chatbot on sales


#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = purchase_amount ~ chatbot, data = df)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
#> -16.702 -14.478  -9.626  13.922  64.648 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)  16.7017     0.8374  19.944  < 2e-16 ***
#> chatbotTRUE  -7.0756     1.1796  -5.998 2.79e-09 ***
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 18.65 on 998 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.0348, Adjusted R-squared:  0.03383 
#> F-statistic: 35.98 on 1 and 998 DF,  p-value: 2.787e-09


#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = purchase_amount ~ chatbot + previous_visit, data = df)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>    Min     1Q Median     3Q    Max 
#> -25.20 -14.57  -8.94  12.58  64.00 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>                Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)     14.9998     1.0410  14.408  < 2e-16 ***
#> chatbotTRUE     -6.8446     1.1788  -5.806 8.58e-09 ***
#> previous_visit   0.7845     0.2868   2.736  0.00633 ** 
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 18.59 on 997 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.04199,    Adjusted R-squared:  0.04007 
#> F-statistic: 21.85 on 2 and 997 DF,  p-value: 5.17e-10


Regression confirms the results of part 1. As the previous visits are not a balanced covariate. They can’t be excluded from the regression


3 Subgroup specific effects
This journal used for this assignment the subgroup: moblie users.


#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = purchase_amount ~ chatbot * mobile_device + previous_visit, 
#>     data = df)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
#> -25.403 -14.450  -8.445  12.549  64.562 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>                               Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)                   15.27384    1.19130  12.821  < 2e-16 ***
#> chatbotTRUE                   -6.82837    1.42580  -4.789 1.93e-06 ***
#> mobile_deviceTRUE             -0.82375    1.79309  -0.459  0.64605    
#> previous_visit                 0.77914    0.28711   2.714  0.00677 ** 
#> chatbotTRUE:mobile_deviceTRUE -0.06455    2.52907  -0.026  0.97964    
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 18.6 on 995 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.04243,    Adjusted R-squared:  0.03858 
#> F-statistic: 11.02 on 4 and 995 DF,  p-value: 9.485e-09


The subgroup of mobile users has no specific effect on the purchase amount, as one can see by the results of the CATE with mobile users, as they are not significant.


4 Logistic regression for purchase


#> 
#> Call:
#> glm(formula = purchase ~ chatbot + previous_visit, family = binomial(link = "logit"), 
#>     data = df)
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>                Estimate Std. Error z value Pr(>|z|)    
#> (Intercept)    -0.24533    0.11384  -2.155   0.0312 *  
#> chatbotTRUE    -0.96827    0.13561  -7.140 9.33e-13 ***
#> previous_visit  0.10643    0.03261   3.264   0.0011 ** 
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> (Dispersion parameter for binomial family taken to be 1)
#> 
#>     Null deviance: 1329.1  on 999  degrees of freedom
#> Residual deviance: 1262.5  on 997  degrees of freedom
#> AIC: 1268.5
#> 
#> Number of Fisher Scoring iterations: 4


e(-0.96827) = 0.3797 -> 1 - 0.3797 = 0.6203
The chatbot is associated with a 62% reduction of purchases. This means that chatbot more than halves the amount of purchases made.

title: My Lab Journal
text:
Content
The content of this journal can be split into two main parts the first part is about the fundamentals of statistics, while the second part introduces different ways to analyse statistic processes.

title: Statistical Concepts
text:
1 Assignment
Calculate

title: Statistical Concepts
text:
1.1 expected value

groupedAge <- sorted_vars_age %>% group_by(age) %>% summarise( n = n())
expectedAge <- weighted.mean(groupedAge[,1],groupedAge[,2])
expectedAge

#> [1] 33.471

title: Statistical Concepts
text:
1.2 variance

varianceAge <- var(groupedAge[[1]])
varianceAge

#> [1] 699.7978

title: Statistical Concepts
text:
1.3 standard deviation

deviationAge <- sd(groupedAge[[1]])
deviationAge

#> [1] 26.45369

#> Rows: 181
#> Columns: 22
#> $ aspiration       <chr> "std", "std", "std", "std", "std", "std", "std", "std…
#> $ doornumber       <chr> "two", "two", "two", "four", "four", "two", "four", "…

#> $ drivewheel       <chr> "rwd", "rwd", "rwd", "fwd", "4wd", "fwd", "fwd", "fwd…

#> $ carlength        <dbl> 168.8, 168.8, 171.2, 176.6, 176.6, 177.3, 192.7, 192.…
#> $ carwidth         <dbl> 64.1, 64.1, 65.5, 66.2, 66.4, 66.3, 71.4, 71.4, 71.4,…
#> $ carheight        <dbl> 48.8, 48.8, 52.4, 54.3, 54.3, 53.1, 55.7, 55.7, 55.9,…
#> $ curbweight       <dbl> 2548, 2548, 2823, 2337, 2824, 2507, 2844, 2954, 3086,…
#> $ enginetype       <chr> "dohc", "dohc", "ohcv", "ohc", "ohc", "ohc", "ohc", "…
#> $ cylindernumber   <chr> "four", "four", "six", "four", "five", "five", "five"…
#> $ enginesize       <dbl> 130, 130, 152, 109, 136, 136, 136, 136, 131, 131, 108…
#> $ fuelsystem       <chr> "mpfi", "mpfi", "mpfi", "mpfi", "mpfi", "mpfi", "mpfi…
#> $ boreratio        <dbl> 3.47, 3.47, 2.68, 3.19, 3.19, 3.19, 3.19, 3.19, 3.13,…
#> $ stroke           <dbl> 2.68, 2.68, 3.47, 3.40, 3.40, 3.40, 3.40, 3.40, 3.40,…
#> $ compressionratio <dbl> 9.00, 9.00, 9.00, 10.00, 8.00, 8.50, 8.50, 8.50, 8.30…
#> $ horsepower       <dbl> 111, 111, 154, 102, 115, 110, 110, 110, 140, 160, 101…
#> $ peakrpm          <dbl> 5000, 5000, 5000, 5500, 5500, 5500, 5500, 5500, 5500,…
#> $ citympg          <dbl> 21, 21, 19, 24, 18, 19, 19, 19, 17, 16, 23, 23, 21, 2…
#> $ highwaympg       <dbl> 27, 27, 26, 30, 22, 25, 25, 25, 20, 22, 29, 29, 28, 2…
#> $ price            <dbl> 13495.00, 16500.00, 16500.00, 13950.00, 17450.00, 152…


After the use of summary() and glimpse(). One can deduct the following from the data.
The data contains data of type double  and character . The data of type double are numeric variables, therefor it is possible to perform mathematical operations with them, which is also done during summary(). However for factor variables (data of type character) it only counts the occurrences.
Furthermore one can read the maxima and minima, as well as the certain mid values from the summary. This is useful to get a feeling of the distribution of the data.

title: Regression and Statistical Inference
section: 3.1 Explain data type and values it can take on
text:
3.1 Explain data type and values it can take on
enginesize is of the type , which means it contains numeric values, which can have decimal points. However enginesize is in the dataframe only represented by integer values. Also it would make no sense for it to be negative.

title: Regression and Statistical Inference
section: 3.2 Plot relationship between enginesize and price
text:
3.2 Plot relationship between enginesize and price









If one plots the enginesize in regard to the prize it can be seen that a bigger engine size correlates to an higher price and this correlation seems to be linear. So increasing the engine size will, most likely result in a higher price and a smaller engine size in a lower price.

title: Regression and Statistical Inference
text:
3.3 Statistical significant


#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = price ~ aspiration + carbody + enginelocation + 
#>     carwidth + enginetype + cylindernumber + enginesize + fuelsystem + 
#>     stroke + peakrpm, data = df)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
#> -5689.4 -1135.6  -167.9  1050.6  9559.7 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>                        Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)          -33093.398  11696.892  -2.829 0.005283 ** 
#> aspirationturbo        3235.549    629.441   5.140 8.16e-07 ***
#> carbodyhardtop        -4445.436   1261.493  -3.524 0.000559 ***
#> carbodyhatchback      -3652.463   1097.252  -3.329 0.001090 ** 
#> carbodysedan          -2801.655   1083.225  -2.586 0.010618 *  
#> carbodywagon          -3366.899   1163.259  -2.894 0.004347 ** 
#> enginelocationrear     6685.578   2083.122   3.209 0.001617 ** 
#> carwidth                633.495    184.487   3.434 0.000764 ***
#> enginetypedohcv       -6524.427   2916.466  -2.237 0.026706 *  
#> enginetypel            2550.542   1346.819   1.894 0.060121 .  
#> enginetypeohc          3605.833    825.070   4.370 2.26e-05 ***
#> enginetypeohcf          306.358   1191.724   0.257 0.797464    
#> enginetypeohcv        -6229.239   1082.598  -5.754 4.52e-08 ***
#> cylindernumberfive   -11038.816   2458.346  -4.490 1.38e-05 ***
#> cylindernumberfour   -11733.891   2312.831  -5.073 1.10e-06 ***
#> cylindernumbersix     -6513.164   1709.745  -3.809 0.000200 ***
#> cylindernumberthree   -5313.956   3696.374  -1.438 0.152560    
#> cylindernumbertwelve -13471.683   2739.257  -4.918 2.21e-06 ***
#> enginesize              147.232     14.184  10.380  < 2e-16 ***
#> fuelsystem2bbl          -85.591    819.650  -0.104 0.916968    
#> fuelsystemmfi         -3453.085   2431.905  -1.420 0.157642    
#> fuelsystemmpfi          235.319    885.475   0.266 0.790782    
#> fuelsystemspdi        -2582.827   1171.745  -2.204 0.028980 *  
#> fuelsystemspfi          748.039   2315.280   0.323 0.747064    
#> stroke                -4869.933    789.248  -6.170 5.69e-09 ***
#> peakrpm                   2.416      0.525   4.601 8.68e-06 ***
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 2165 on 155 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.938,  Adjusted R-squared:  0.928 
#> F-statistic: 93.83 on 25 and 155 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16


If one takes a look at the before found linear model, one can see that the engine size is statistical significant with an p-value less than alpha = 0.001. The same can be seen by the linear model without variable selection.

title: Directed Acyclic Graphs
text:
2.1 Regress satisfaction on follow_ups


#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = satisfaction ~ follow_ups, data = df)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
#> -12.412  -5.257   1.733   4.506  12.588 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)  78.8860     4.2717  18.467 1.04e-10 ***
#> follow_ups   -3.3093     0.6618  -5.001 0.000243 ***
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 7.923 on 13 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.658,  Adjusted R-squared:  0.6316 
#> F-statistic: 25.01 on 1 and 13 DF,  p-value: 0.0002427

title: Directed Acyclic Graphs
section: 2.2 Regress satisfaction on follow_ups and account for subscription
text:
2.2 Regress satisfaction on follow_ups and account for subscription


#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = satisfaction ~ follow_ups + subscription, data = df)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
#> -4.3222 -2.1972  0.3167  2.2667  3.9944 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>                      Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)           26.7667     6.6804   4.007  0.00206 ** 
#> follow_ups             2.1944     0.7795   2.815  0.01682 *  
#> subscriptionPremium   44.7222     5.6213   7.956 6.88e-06 ***
#> subscriptionPremium+  18.0722     2.1659   8.344 4.37e-06 ***
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 2.958 on 11 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.9597, Adjusted R-squared:  0.9487 
#> F-statistic: 87.21 on 3 and 11 DF,  p-value: 5.956e-08
